column1: Gherla (Romanian pronunciation: [ˈɡerla]; Hungarian: Szamosújvár; German: Neuschloss) is a municipality in Cluj County
column2: Romania (in the historical region of Transylvania). It is located 45 kilometres (28 mi) from Cluj-Napoca on the river Someșul Mic

column1: The city was formerly known as Armenopolis (Armenian: Հայաքաղաք Hayakaghak; German: Armenierstadt; Hungarian: Örményváros) because it was populated by Armenians.

A clay tablet containing a fragmentary Old Persian cuneiform of the Achaemenid king Darius I was found at Gherla in 1937. It may be connected to Darius I's epigraphic activities  in relation to his Scythian campaign of 513 BC as reported by Herodotus.The locality was first recorded in 1291 as a village named Gherlahida
column2: (probably derived from the Slavic word grle
column3: meaning "ford"). The second name was Armenian

column9: Gherla was part of the Kingdom of Hungary comitatus of Szolnok-Doboka. It was again part of Hungary between 1940–1944.

column1: The modern city was built in the early 18th century by Armenians
column2: successors of the Cilician Armenian diaspora
column3: who had originally settled in Crimea and Moldavia
column4: and moved to Transylvania sometime after 1650. After a two years' campaign by the Armenian-Catholic Bishop Oxendius Vărzărescu
column5: they converted from the Armenian Apostolic Church to the Armenian Catholic Church.Gherla is the seat of the Ordinariate for Catholics of Armenian Rite in Romania
column6: as well as that of a Greek-Catholic diocese – the Cluj-Gherla Diocese (suffragan to the Greek-Catholic Archbishop of Alba Iulia and Făgăraș-Blaj
column7: who resided in Blaj). In the center of the city lie the Saint Gregory the Illuminator and the Holy Trinity Armenian Cathedral. The main Armenian-Catholic church was built in 1792. The Greek Catholic diocese was created by the Papal Bull Ad Apostolicam Sedem of November 26
column9: and the first bishop was Ioan Alexi.

column1: A Habsburg fortress was built here and converted to a prison in 1785. During the Communist regime
column2: the prison was used for political detainees (see Gherla prison). Today it is a Romanian  high-security prison.

column1: The town is often visited by Orthodox pilgrims on their way to the nearby village of Nicula and Nicula Monastery.

Gherla also had a significant Jewish population which was decimated during the Holocaust. After the war most of the remaining Jewish population left the city. The Synagogue and the Holocaust Memorial Monument are visited by tourists from many countries.
